title: UK weather forecast: Met Office issue new warning over heavy rain and flooding

The Met Office has warned the latest round of heavy rain is on its way and could mean more flooding and disruption in parts of the UK today.

The forecaster has issued a yellow weather warning for the south and south-east of England this morning, advising that some homes and businesses could be flooded once again.

The Met Office has reissued its warning to reflect that the heaviest rains are now expected to hit the east.

The warning is in place from noon until midnight today, as the Met Office raises the alarm that parts of the UK could face power cuts and a chance some communities could be "cut off" by flooded roads.

(Image: Anita Maric / SWNS)

Delays to train and road travel are also expected.

The heavy downpours are being predicted ahead of worsening weather next week.

Typhoon Hagibis is expected to make its effects felt in the UK in days to come.

The storm has killed dozens of people in Japan where the Rugby World Cup is currently being held.

Key matches have been scrapped due to the terrible weather, prompting outrage as the competition heats up.

Met Office Science earlier tweeted: "As warm moist air from Typhoon Hagibis comes north to clash with a cold front pushing south-east across Russia, the strengthening temperature contrast will accelerate the Jet Stream by 100mph in 48 hours!

"By affecting the jet, Hagibis could influence UK weather next week."

Today's Yellow weather warning stretchers from just south of the Humber, and covers the entire east and south east coast of England.

The heavy rain warning covers an area as far west as Nottingham, Leicester, Oxford and Salisbury and as far south and east as London and and Norwich.

Leicestershire was among the cities pummelled by the recent weeks' flooding, which also led to sodden chaos on the Isle of Man.
